description.narrative: Programmet syftar till att minska fattigdomen och öka hållbarheten i det skogliga utnyttjandet inom områden där lokalbefolkningen nu fått juridisk säkerhet vad gäller mark- och skogsrättigheter.Detta ska ske genom en innovativ modell som stärker den tekniska och organisatoriska kompetensen på lokalnivå, och aktivt bidrar till en ny och mer förmånlig länkning till landets skogsindustri.

The overriding objective is to reduce povertry and increase sustainability in productive forestry within areas now securely possessed by local communities. This will be achieved through an innovative model of forestry management, which strengthens technical and organizational capacities of local communities and thereby permits a new and more favorable linking to the forest industry.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: According to the intervention logic, the agreement partner - the Puma Foundation (Fondo Puma in Spanish) - was going to provide technical assistance and capacity building to small-hold forest communities in sustainable forestry management. Further it should establish an inclusive community owned forest industry which would in turn produce environmentally sustainable and certified timber products (for instance wooden flooring) for the local and export markets.
The Programme was initially planned as a joint venture between USAID, the Dutch and the Swedish Development Cooperation. However, USAID did not enter the programme. The Netherlands co-founded the programme until 2012, when the Dutch cooperation withdraws from the country. Sweden continued supporting the programme until the end of 2015. During the first five years, 2010 through 2014, progress reports showed good performance towards the objectives: 40 small-hold forest communities were trained in sustainable forest management; approximately 375 000 hectares of forest had sustainable management plans; bio-diversity increased in areas under sustainable management; the forest industry ‘CONFOR’ was established as a private company with the forest community organisations as minority shareholders and the PUMA Foundation as majority shareholder. The CONFOR was conformed of three saw-mills. In 2013 CONFOR started to produce high quality timber products for the local market.
The 2013 mid-term project review confirmed positive achievements, but also high-lighted some concerns. Besides the decreasing market price on timber products, it stressed that high turnover rate among member of staff and the complicated legal structure of the CONFOR posed a risk to sustainability.
In late November 2015 (activity period ended October 2015) the Puma Foundation suddenly informed the Embassy that the programme had run into financial difficulties and that the CONFOR was on the verge of bankruptcy. According to the Puma Foundation, the main reason behind the difficulties to sustain programme outcomes was related to the dramatic fall in global and national market prices on timber products. Market prices of timber products at the end of 2015 were only 30% of the price level when the programme started in 2009.
The Puma Foundation had not given the Embassy any previous communication on the financial difficulties. On the contrary, in a meeting held in mid-September 2015, the Puma Foundation reported that in spite of experiencing the impact of low market prices on timber products, progress was according to plan.
The final progress report (for the year 2015, received March 2016) confirmed that the Puma Foundation had not been able to sustain achievements made during previous years. Given the circumstances, the Embassy decided not to do a full-scale outcome/impact end of programme evaluation. Instead, a consultant was contracted to carry out an independent analysis and suggest realistic solutions to CONFORs problems and recommend a way forward in order to save at least some of the investments made (Contribution id: 10008).
The consultant made a thorough field investigation, visiting the three forest industries, interviewing staff at the three saw mills, community representatives and local and national stakeholders. The study concluded that even if the programme was relevant in relation to local needs at the time of initiating activities in 2009, the forest industry CONFOR was unsustainable at current market prices. Production costs exceeded revenues at basically all stages in the production chain. One of the three sawmills had already stopped production and the remaining two were operating at minimum level. Any substantial increase in market prices of timber products are not likely to occur within the coming five year period. Such financial difficulties was not only limited to CONFOR, but had affected many other timber companies, some of which had ceased to operate.
The consultant assessed that it was highly unlikely that additional donor funds could solve the problem, but rather only extend the unsustainable production for another year or so. The most realistic alternative would be to split the CONFOR and transfer the three sawmill plants to new owners and use these as combined training centres and production units in collaboration with local universities. This was also the recommendation conveyed by the Embassy to the PUMA Foundation and the CONFOR management. However as the agreement between the PUMA Foundation and the Embassy had ended and CONFOR is a private company, the responsibility to carry out the appropriate measures legally lies with the CONFOR management.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
